div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,406] ALEXANDRIA, TUESSDAY, JANUARY 30, 1906. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

TUESDAY, JANUARY 30, 1906.

div.head: THE NATIONAL BANK.
div.p: The death of Sir Elwin Palmer has naturally set all Egypt speculating as to who will be his successor. The appointment in question is the highest salaried post in the country, and even if we include official appointments it is one of the most important billets in Egypt. It is therefore incumbent upon us to give utterance to the general opinion upon this great appoiot ment with no uncertain voice, for we know well that our opinions on the matter are entire- ly in accord with those of the pubic. The National Bank of Egypt, be it remembered, is a national institution, controlled and conduct- ed by British subjects. We Britishers are therefore morally responsible for the way in which it is earned on, and also for the integ- rity of its governing staff. The responsibility of the selection of a successor to Sir Elwin Palmer rests in the main upon the totelary Power, which, in setting up a State Bank, should have provided proper safeguards and taken efficient precautions to ensure the choice falling upon one whose character, career, con- nections, and social position are a guarantee of his probity. In any event it cannot be too strongly insisted upon that the Governor of the National Bank of Egypt should be a personage not merely enjoying the fullest con- fidence of the commercial and financial world, but one whose activities should be restricted to the National Bank alone. We therefore consider that it is the duty of Lord Cromer and Sir Ernest Cassel to take the necessary safeguards that the new Governor should devote his service exclusively to the National Bank and give companies and com pony-promoting a wide berth. The bank's business, one would think, is sufficiently exten- sive to take up all one man's time, and the salary is sufficiently remunerative to enable him to withstand, the temptation of dabbling in other financial enterprises. Fancy the Governor of the Bank of England mixing himself up with a host of petty industrial limited liability companies. The idea sounds preposterous. Yet the National Bank of Egypt holds a position in this country analogous with, if not identical to, that of the Bank of England at home. Even though it be not stipulated in the terms of his appointment, it ought to be part of the unwritten law that the Governor of the National Bank shall not engage in any business unconnected with that of the beak itself. We have always wondered that the Egyptian Government did not lay down some such stipulation when the bank was founded. At any rate, now is the time to enforce this most salutary rule, and it will be certainly to the interest of the bank itself, no less than to that of Egypt's financial prestige, if the Governor elect should take that strict view of his high position and responsibility.

div.head: CAPE TO CAIRO.
div.p: The great trunk railway through Africa from south to north, projected by the genius of Mr. Rhodes, has made astonishingly quick progress since it crowed the Zambesi at Vic- toria Falls. When Sir Charles Metcalfe lately visited rail-head, it was 260 miles beyond the great river, and had been advancing at the rate of a mile per diem. Apparently, no engineer- ing difficulties had been encountered up to that data, the country being level and very little broken by watercourses. But a few miles far- ther on the Kafue River presented itself, neces- sitating the construction of a bridge 1,600 feet long. In European countries that would be regarded as a tough and prolonged labour, but the Briton in Africa accepts even more formidale obstacles as all in the day's work. While the bridge is being made and got into position necessary earth work is being raH1/ carried out on the farther ride, leaving nothing else to be done for nearly a hundred miles than laying sleepers and rails. Should all go well, it is calculated that by next Midsummer there will be unbroken railway communication between Cape Town and the Broken Hill zinc and lead mines, nearly 400 miles beyond the Zambesi. But something even more important than the provision of quicker and cheaper transport facilities is being accomplished. Sir Charles Metcalfe, who extended his explora- tions far away from the line, reports that the natives highly appreciate the greater security for life and property which has accompanied the establishment of white administration. By nature, the inhabitants of Northern Rhodesia are as a rule peaceful folks, well content so long as they are permitted to reap the fruits industry, and they have to thank the coming of the white man for rescue from the savage tyranny of their fiercer neighbours.

div.head: A. S. C.
div.p: Lieut. A. B. Wakelin has been appointed to the A.S.C. at Alexandria in succession to Lieut Page.

div.head: Sudan Irrigation Service.
div.p: Messrs. Marco A. Frajs, Adolphe Botte and Maurice Press have born appointed to the Sudan irrigation service at an annual salary of LE. 240.
Khédivial Reception.
H. H. the Khedive will hold a reception at Abdeen Palace on Sunday next, on the occa- sion of the commencement of the Kourban Beyram festival, for persons resident in Cairo.
In Mourning 1

"Al Zaber," an Arabic daily paper published in Cairo, has come out in mourning on the occassion of the opening of the Nile Red Sea Railway, which it declares is the last nail in the coffin of Egypt's old domination over the Sudan.
Egyptian Shells.

The January shell sales took place in London on the 19th inst. Of the Egyptian variety, 140 packages were offered and 60 sold steadily. Stout and thin medium 804 ; chicken 75s ; oysters 52s 6d , broken pieces 42s ; grubby pickings 31s to 35s.
The Abyssinian Bank.

A notice has been issued in London that in order to comply with the requirements of the Stock Exchange, holders of scrip of the Bank of Abyssinia issued in London are requested to deposit their scrip with the Na- tional Bank of Egypt, 4 and 5, King Wil- liam-Street, in order to have the deletion of the words "when fully paid" initialled.
New Employment Registry.

The British Chamber of Commerce gives notice that it has commenced an employment register, which may be oonsa 1 ted by mem- bers requiring clerical or other assistance. Applications will be received, free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts in Egypt. Address, Secretary, British Chamber of Commerce, Alexandria. [Advt.]
Luxor Sporting Club.

The fancy dress ball, in aid of the Luxor Hospital, will he held at the Luxor Hotel on Tuesday, February 6, dancing to commence at 8 45 p.m. Last year £23 was raised by this hall and given to the hospital. Tickets (20 P.T. each) can be had of the secretary (Rev. A. W. Gross), the treasurer (Mr. Seville), and the doctors on Messrs. T. Cook & Son's steamers.
A Greek "Drame Passionnel."

Yesterday a young Greek was walking on the banks of the Mahmoudieh Canal, when he was met by his rival in the affections of a girl. The latter drew his knife, which he plunged into the other Greek's stomach, and leaving him for dead, tossed the knife into the canal and made off. The victim did not succumb, but he lies in a precarious condition in hospital.
A Sudan Railway Tale.

At a meeting held at Doncaster during the election Sir Frederick Fison in the course of his speech related a very amusing story told to him by Lord Balfour of Burleigh with regard to the awkward conditions of rail- way working in the Sudan desert. A telegram was received at the head office, "Station- master dead ; what shall we do !" The reply sent was, "Bury him ; but be sure he is quite dead." Then followed the return message, "Stationmaster dead. Buried. Hit him on the head with a fishplate !"
P. W. D. Salaries.

The annual salaries of Mohamed Bey Hech- met, chief engineer in the 5th Irrigation Circle, and of Ahmed Effendi Fauxi, chief engineer at the Assiout Dam, have been raised to L.E. 432 ; those of Ibrahim Effendi Zaki, chief engineer at the Delta Dam, Mo- hamed Effendi Mamour, chief engineer in the First Irrigation Circle, Mahmoud Effendi Fahrny, chief engineer in the Z fta Irrigation Circle, Mohamed Effet di Enayet, chief engi- neer In the Ghirgeh Irrigation Circle, and Mohamed Effendi Salig, chief engineer for the Ismailieh Canal, have been raised to L.E. 360.
A Hint for Advertisers.

A unique and brilliant advertising scheme was conceived the other day by a Brooklyn business man, which might he carried into effect in Cherif Pacha-Street or some of the Cairo thoroughfares. He had his advertising sign affixed in raised letters to the tyre of an automobile so that when the letters were by an arrangement, coated over with white paint the machine painted his advertisement on the asphalt wherever it was driven. The Brooklyn street-cleaning commissioner, being an unresponsive soul who did not appreciate a stroke of genius like this on the pavement threatened him with the police, and promptly squelched the whole scheme.
Two Old Egyptian Books.

Dr. Wallis Budge of the British Museum, has made a translation of, and written a commentary on, the curious Egyptian books known as The Book of what is in Hades' and 'The Book of the Gates' respectively. These two works give pictures of the life after death which differ in many respects from that which can be drawn from the more generally known 'Book of the Dead,' and they are a good deal later in date, not having been, apparently, reduced to writing until the eighteenth or nineteenth dynasty. Dr. Budge's translation will be published early next month by Messrs. Kegan Paul & Co., and will form the first English version of these books which has yet appears.

div.head: THE BRITISH REPRESENTATIVE
LONDON PRESS TRIBUTE. HIS DETERMINATION TO REMAIN AT THE HELM.
div.p: The announcement, which Lord Cromer made on Saturday at Port Sudan as to'his determination to remain in Egypt as long as he possibly can, has caused a very favourable impression in the City and also in the Press. In an article on the inauguration and the speech the "Standard" states that the most secure guarantee for the development and prosperity of the Sudan is Lord Cromer's de- cision to remain in Egypt. Eulogistic notices pervade the Press, and the "Daily Telegraph" declares that the "proconsular sceptre of Great Britain" was never wielded by a stronger man than Lord Cromer.

div.head: EGYPTIAN TRUST AND INVESTMENT.
div.p: M. Pericles Glymenopolo, administrator of the Egyptian Trust and Investment, Limited was elected a director of the Alexandria and Ramleh Railway Company at the annual meeting held yesterday at the company's offices, and we understand that arrangements have been made whereby Baron de Easel Bey, general manager of the Egyptian Trust and Investment Ltd., will join the board of the Alexandria Tramway Company. These appointments would seem to indicate and confirm the rumours which have been current here for some time past to the effect that the Egyptian Trust and Investment, Ltd. is largely interested in the Alexandria Tram way Company. The development of the town and surround- ing suburbs is increasing rapidly to such an extent that it is evident additional tram lines and branches will be necessary, consequently this means larger and increased revenues for the company. The Egyptian Trust and Investment, who are proprietors of a large extension of land at Ramleh and in the suburbs, have evidently gauged the situation clearly and taken time by the forelock in securing a large interest in such a prosperous local undertaking as the Alexandria Tramways.

div.head: CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT
div.p: We understand that this company intends making a bid next season for the supply of the London market with dates from their cases, where the date trees are to he frond in large numbers and the fruit is of the finest quality, quite equal in every respect to that of other countries which now ship to the English markets, vis., Tunis, Algiers, snd the Persian Gulf. The latter place exports some 150,000 cases annually to London and a great deal more to America. The cases of Khargeh also produce oranges of a very superior description, and judging by them as a sample of what the oases can grow it is a fair promise of the future agricultural prosperity of the regions owned by the Corporation, the lands of which should considerably increase in value on the completion of the new railway now being laid to Khargeh from Farchont, where it joins the State railway line to Upper Egypt. The opening of these cases should prove a valuable addition to agricultural Egypt and explains the statement made by Lord Cromer in his 1904 report, where, referring to the limitations of Egypt from the development point of view, be says : "Possibly something may eventually be done ..... in the cases of the Lybian desert." Certainly, judging by the boring of wells, building of railways, export of fruit, and some other projects contemplated, this looks very much like something being done, and Lord Cromer's prophecies are already being gradually fulfilled.

div.head: EGYPT AND THE WHITE STAR LINE
div.p: Readers of this paper will observe in our advertising columns particulars of the sailings of the White Star Line from Alexandria to Naples (reached in four days) and America. This service is undoubtedly one of the best for reaching Europe, and should be wall patronised be the many travellers now in Egypt, and who will soon be contemplating their return journey. The immediate sailings are: SS. Canopic (13000 tons) Feb. 1 Republic (15400 tons) „ 15 Romanic 11400 tons) „ 22 Canopic (13000 tons) Mar. 15 Republic (15100 tons) „ 29 and the fares from Alexandria to Naples are £10 and upwards. Bookings may be effected at the White Star Agents in Alexandria, Messrs. J. Ross and Co., and at Cook's Tourist Offices in Cairo.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Moss liner Tabor sailed from Malta yesterday afternoon and is due here on Friday morning with passengers, mails, and general cargo. The S.S. City of Khios sailed from Liverpool on Sunday for Alexandria.

div.head: LORD CROMER AT KHARTOUM.
VISIT TO THE TOWN. FESTIVITIES AT THE PALACE.
div.p: Lord Cromer and party arrived at Khartoom at 9.30 a.m. to-day and were met by the prin- cipal officers and officials of the Government, the chief sheikhs,the Grand Mufti of the Sudan, the invited members of the Legislative Council and the Press correspondents. His Lordship went by train round Khartoum, the train being in charge of Colonel Stanton and Bim- bashi Amory. Lord Cromer on his arrival was saluted with 21 guns, fired by the Egyptian Artillery, and a guard of honour of the Egyptian Army was mounted at the Palace. Receptions were held at Khartoom North and Khartoum. Tomorrow morning Lord Cromer will pay a visit to Omdurman, and a dinner will be given in his honour at the Palace in the even- ing. A visit to Gordon College will be paid on Wednesday, on the afternoon of which a garden party will be held at the Palace. On Wednes day the Press correspondents have been kindly invited to dine with Sir Rudolf von Slatin Pacha, and on Friday we leave on the return journey. Our train journey to Khartoum was of the most interesting description. The train was under the charge of Bimboashi Lord, who arranged everything in the most satisfactory manner. He will have charge of Lord Cromer's train on the return journey.

div.head: KOREIMA—-ABOU HAMED LINE.
div.p: I learn that the Koreima-Abon Hamed rail- way line was completed on the 27th inst., but it is not yet open to traffic.

div.head: FIELD DAY IN CAIRO.
div.p: The British troops fencing the Cairo garrison are to engage in field manœnvres on Thursday next, commencing at 10 a.m. The troops will be at the rendezvous assigned to them at 9.30 a.m. Officers and troops of the Egyptian Army will also take part in the operations. The following will be the composition of the forces : — Blue Force—Half battalion 1st Bn. K.R.R. Corps ; 1 squadron Egyptian Cavalry ; 4 guns, Egyptian Artillery ; 1 battalion Egyptian In- fantry. Red Force—2 troops M.M.P. ; 1 company M.I. ; 2nd Bn. Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers ; 2 guns Egyptian Artillery. The following will be the commanders and Staff officers of the forces :- O.C. Blue Force Major C.L.E. Robertson- Eustace, D.S.O,1st Bn. K.R.R. Corps. Staff Officer—Captain C. W. Maclean, E A. O.C. Red Force — Major C.J.L. Davidson, D.S.O., 2nd Bn. Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers. Staff Officer—To be detailed by O.C.Force. The umpire staff consists of :— Umpire in Chief—Brigadier General G.M. Bullock, C.B. Umpires—Lt. Colonel H. G. K Matchett, E.A. (accompanied by 2 Native Staff officers); Major G. C. Knight, D.A.A. and QM.G. ; Captain T.B. Bayley, Staff Captain. Umpire Blue Force—Lt. Colonel R.C.C.Cox, 2nd Bn. Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers. Assistant Umpire - Captain H. Gordon, A.A.G., E.A. Umpire Red Force—Lt Colonel C.J. Mark- ham 1st Bn K R R Corps. Assistant Umpire—Lieutenant K.R Edge- worth, E.A.

div.head: FAYOUM LIGHT RAILWAY.
FURTHER DISCLOSURES.
div.p: Following my last notes on the state of affairs of this company, I have gathered the following, and would especially call the atten- tion of those Ministers who are responsible for its proper administration to remove the bur- den of inconvenience and annoyance the inha- bitants of Fayoum province are groaning under. It appears the company have all at once disco- vered they are using more than double the amount of coal they were 18 months ago, and without considering any reason why, decided each engine should have the same as previous- ly (about 100% less than last month). This order has been in force about a week, and every day one or two of those on the longer runs have finished their fuel when only half- way back home and there the passengers have had to remain until and employe walked to the nearest telephone "for a special" with coal to be sent. In each case these trains have been two or three hours late. On Sunday the train left Tamia at 6 a.m., arriving at Fayoum at 3.50 p.m. The distance, be it noted, is 25 kilo- meters. "Magnificent," and proves what can be done when one tries. On Monday I had occasion to call at the company's offices at 10.30 a.m. but- it is a positive fact- in the whole block of offices there was not a single living being, not even a bowab awake or asleep at the door. I was therefore unable to transact my business. Truly when the cat is away the mice will play. All these things prevent traffic among passengers, and will account for the continual decrease of receipts. How long will it last?

div.head: THE LATE SIR E. PALMER.
FUNERAL SERVICE.
TRIBUTE TO HIS POPULARITY.
div.p: The immense congregation, consisting as it did of persons of all ranks and of all nationali- ties in Cairo, which assembled at All Saints' Church, Cairo, yesterday afternoon to take part in the service in memory of the late Sir Elwin Palmer, K.C.B., K.C.M.G., was a perfect testi- mony to the great regret which is felt in Egypt at the death of the man who has for so many years figured so prominently in this country. The nave and aisles of the church were crowded and many people were unable to find seats. Of the members of the bereaved family, Lieut. Palmer (son) and Sir William and Lady Erskine Ward were present, and his Highness the Khedive was represented by H.E. El Lewa Watson Pasha. Among the congregation were:- Lady Cromer and Lady Beatrice Thynne, their Excellencies Mustapha Pacha Fehmy, Scandar Pacha Fehmy, Hussein Pacha Fehkry, Boutros Pasha Ghali, Ahmed Mazloum Pacha, Ibrahim Fouad Pacha, Mohamed Abani Pacha, Boghos Pacha Nubar, Sir John Rogers Pacha, Johnson Pacha, Mr. P. W. Machell, Anis Pacha, Mansfield Pacha, Mr. Moberley, Rear-Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield, Sir Horace Pinching, General, Mrs. and Miss Bullock, Mr. and Mrs. George Royal, Mr. Rowlatt, Mr. John Home, Mr. G. Scott-Dalgleish, Mr. Cookson, Mr. MacCloughlin, Mr. R.H. du Boulay, Mr. Felix Suares, Mr. M. Cattani, Mr. P. W. Stout, Mr. G. In the chancel and south aisle there were innumerable and beautiful wreaths and other floral tributes bearing the names, among others, of the Khedive, Lord and Lady Cromer, Sir Reginald and Lady Wingate, Sir William Garatin, Sir John and Lady Rogers, Johnson Pacha, Col. and Mrs. Asser, Capt. and Mrs. Maclean, Mr. and George Royle, Mrs. A.Q. The service, which consisted of the order for the burial of the dead, with the omission of the committal sentences, was read by the Very Rev. Dean Butcher, D D, who was assisted by the Rev. Thompson Burns, M.A. While the congregation was assembling Mr. Peacock, who presided at the organ, played Chopin's Funeral March, and at the conclusion of the service the "Dead March in Saul," the congregation stand- ing, and this was followed by Mendelssohn's Funeral March.
MESSAGE FROM THE KING.

Lady Palmer has received the following telegram from Sir Ernest Cassell:- "I have just communicated the sad news to the King, who commands me to convey to you his sym- pathy at the great loss which you have suffered."

div.head: EGYPTIAN COTTON IN INDIA.
A SUCCESSFUL EXPERIMENT.
div.p: The report published by the Board of Land Records and Agriculture states that the grow- ing of Egyptian and other varieties of cotton is being carried on steadily in Upper Shand, India. "Yannovitch," the finest of the Egyptian varieties, but regarded as the most delicate of those experimented with, has suffered the smallest amount of deterioration in staple (12 1/2 per cent.) from the quality of the Egyptian- grown product, while "Mitaffifi," which is con- sidered most robust, has shown the greatest amount of deterioration. The general results must, however, but considered as satisfactory in yield as compared even with the Egyptian crop, and by the figures the best Egyptian variety should prove 250 per cent. more profitable to the cultivator than the indigenous Sindhi variety. In all, about 1,500 acres of Egyptian cotton were sown in the past season.

div.head: QUARANTINE REMOVED.
div.p: A telegram from Constantinople states that, by a decision of the Superior Board of Health, the medical inspection in force in Turkish ports against arrivals from Alexandria has been removed.

div.head: DEATH OF KING CHRISTIAN.
THE QUEEN'S FATHER.
AGED MONARCH PASSES AWAY QUIETLY.
div.p: The King is dead. At the usual audience in the morning he felt indisposed and retired to rest until lunch. The Dowager Empress of Russia visited him at three in the afternoon. Finding him ill she summoned the family. He expired peacefnlly at 3.40. (Reuter)
Copenhagen, January 29.
King Christian died at 3.40 p.m. (Haras)
Copenhagen, January 29.
The King passed away quietly. In the morning he had granted the usually audiences. (H.)

Christian IX, King of Denmark, fourth son of the late Duke William of Schleswig-Holstein- Sonderburg-Glücksburg, was born on April 8, 1818. Before his succession to the Crown he was Inspector-General and Commander in Chief of the Danish Calvary. The succession was vested in him by the protocol of London, May 8, 1862, and he ascended the throne on the death of Frederic VII., Nov. 15, 1868. On his acces- sion, the position of affairs with respect to Schleswig-Holstein was completely changed. The son of the Duke of Augustenburg im- mediately laid claim to the sovereignty of the duchies, although his father had for a com- pensation resigned all his rights in 1852. The independence of Holstein more especially, and of a portion of Schleswig, was warmly espoused by the German Diet, which forthwith ordered the advance of a Federal army to occupy the debstable territory, for the purpose of enforcing its enfranchisement from Danish rule. Before matters had proceeded far, Austria and Prussia determined to interfere, and by a combined armed occupation of the disputed territory to bring the question to an issue independently of the Diet, and in opposition to the wishes of that body. They accordingly invaded the duchies, which, after a hotly contested cam- paign, they succeeded in wresting from Den- mark, also taking temporary possession of Jutland Christian IX, disappointed in not obtaining assistance from some European Power, after the failure of the conference con- vened in London in 1884, which failure was in some measure attributable to the obstinacy of the Danish Government entered into negotiations for peace with Prussia and Austria, and a treaty was signed at Vienna, Oct 30, 1864. The King of Denmark renounced all his rights to Schleswig-Holstein and Lauenburg, and in 1866 the two German Powers quarrelled over the spoil. Since then his Majesty had sought to develop the interior sources and popular institutions of his country. A new constitution was inaugurated in Nov., 1866, when the late King opened the first Rigsdag, the members of which were elect- ed in accordance with the new electoral law. The army and navy have also been thoroughly reorganised agriculture and commerce have received a great stimulus, and several railways have been constructed. Christian IX. and Queen Louise visited the Queen (then Prin- cess of Wales) at Marlborough House, in March, 1867. The marriage of the Crown Prince of Denmark with the Princesa Louisa, daughter of the King of Sweden, at Stockholm, on July 28, 1869, was hailed as a pledge of union between the two countries. His Majesty granted a new constitution to Iceland which came into operation in August, 1874, that being the thousandth year of Iceland's existence as a nation. He went to Reikiajvik on the occasion of the anniversary being celebrated, and on his return paid a flying visit to Leith and Edinburgh, Aug. 18,1874. He visited the Emperor Wil- liam II. at Berlin in August, 1888, and in the autumn of 1889 was visited by the Emperor of Russia and his family. In 1842 he married a daughter of the Landgrave William of Hesse-Cassel by whom he has had six children, and among them the King of Grewe, our own Queen Alexandra, and the Princess Dagmar, married to the late Tsar of Russia. On May 26, 1892, the King and Queen of Denmark celebrated their golden wedding amid many demonstrations of loyalty and popular rejoicing. The latest event in his family was the selection of his grandson as King of Norway.

div.head: WEATHER AT SUEZ.
div.p: Yesterday forenoon Suez experienced a mort violent sandstorm, accompanied by rain, which lasted practically till late in the afternoon, and owing to which the gale abated. Several native lighters suffered considerably, but no life was lost. Navigation in the Canal was rendered most difficult, and many ships had to tie up for a short time, till the storm was over.

div.head: AMATEUR ATHLETIC CLUB.
div.p: At the general meeting of the Alexandria Amateur Athletic Club, held last evening at H. B. M.'s Consulate, the following committee was elected for the ensuing year:- Messrs. P.W. Carver, H.J. Dickson, F.C. Haselden, W.T. Smith, J.P. Jones, G.C. Stevenson, W. Thomas, J.A. Scott, K.P. Birley, G.T. McLean, S.R.P. Carver, and R.R. McLean.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The Princes Louis and Antoine of Orleans and Braganza arrived at Alexandria yesterday by the North German Lloyd steamer.

The Kaiser, on the occasion of the anniversary of his birthday, yesterday conferred the title of Baron on Dr. Rucker-Jenisch. German Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General at Cairo The family is of Bavarian origin and was ennobled in the fifteenth century, but the main line of the family, to which the German Agent at Cairo belongs, suppressed its titular rank on settling in tie free city of Hamburg in the seventeenth century.
The Count and Countess de Lesseps, who are at present staying in Cairo, will leave for Marseilles on the 12th February by the Orient and Pacific Company's steamer.

The celebrated French composer, M. Camille Saint-Seens, left Alexandria by the Austrian Lloyd's S.S. Semiramis for Brindisi on route for Monte Carlo, where he will take charge of the rehearsals of "L'Ancètre." During his stay in Cairo he was the guest of Prince Mohamed Aly Pacha.
Professor Percy E. Newbury, who takes a great interest in Egyptological subjects, has left Cairo for Upper Egypt, where he will spend three weeks studying the famous temples around Luxor and Assouan.

Sir John Evans, for many years President of the Egypt Exploration Pond, was last week, on resigning the chairmanship of the Herts County Council, presented at Hertford with a silvergilt loving cup and a half length portrait of himself by the Hon. John Collier, subscribed for by his colleagues in the public life of the county.

The following passengers left for Upper Egypt by the train de luxe on Saturday :- Major L'Estrange Johnstone, Mr. and Mrs. Runny, Mr. Samand, Mr. and Mrs. String Fellow, Mr. R. Y. Davis, Mr. P. ML Pencovid, Mr. Reynolds, Mr. Rodrcunachi, Messrs. Frost and Weston, Mr. J. R. Davis, Gen. C. Podiateami, Mr. P. Casotti, Mr. J. Greenwood, Mr. Frost and party of 3, Rev. B. The marriage of Mlle. Ketty Pantasides Alexakis to M. Nicolas Papapandelides took place at the New Khédivial Hotel on Sunday, the Greek Patriarch officiating. There was a large and fashionable gathering present, and the buffet provided by the hotel was of the most delectable description.

Lord de Clifford, who, with his aunt, the Hon. Maud Russell, has been staying lately at the Savoy Hotel, has now gone for a trip up the river. Lord de Clifford, who only came of age quite recently, represents an extremely ancient peerage, standing fourth on the roll of English barons, and is the twenty-fifth holder of the title which was created by Edward the First more than six centuries ago. The name of Dé Clifford was known well in the feudal days, but owing to the failure of the male line the title has been held by members of the Tufton, Southwell, and Russell families. There is at present no male heir to the peerage, Lord de Clifford's co-heiresses being his aunts, the Hon. Maud Russell and the Hon. Mrs. Reginald Corbet. Lord de Clifford is one of the very youngest masters of fox hounds in the United Kingdon.

div.head:
ALGECIRAS CONFERENCE.
GERMANY AND PEACE
A POLICY OF CONTRADICTION.

div.p: At the banquet of the German colony on the occasion of the Emperor's birthday, Prince Radolin, in proposing a toast to the health of President Loubet and M. Falliéres, said that he was convinced that the Conference at Algericas would result in the solution of the Moroccan question in a manner satisfactory to all A Franco-German rapprochement would be the surest guarantee of peace, which nobody desires more than the Emperor. (R.)

At the Reichstag banquet, the President said that the famous landing of the Emperor at Tangier had diverted the question of Morocco into a course favourable to Germany, but to ensure peace they must be able to knock on the head anybody attempting to disturb it. The Reichstag must therefore support the Emperor's policy and vote the means for inspiring respect. (Reuter)

The speech of Prince Radolin has caused an excellent impression here, but that of the Pre sident of the Reichstag has been received with amassment and irritation, in view of the pre- vailing cordiality and confidence. (Reuter)

div.head:
The Yemen Rising.
ARAB DEFEAT BY TURKS.

div.p: The Turks have defeated the Arabs and recaptured the arms and ammunition lost in the defeat mentioned in despatches of the 8th instant. (Reuter)

div.head:
BULGARIA AND TURKEY.
TURKISH INTERVENTION NOT TOLERATED.

div.p: Replying to Turkish objections regarding the Serbo-Bulgarian Customs Union, which was the Original cause of the Austro-Servian dis pute, Bulgaria energetically refuses to tolerate Turkish intervention. (Reuter)

The meeting of the Pan Russian Mussulman Congress has been prohibited, although dele- gates arrived from the most distant parts of the Empire, including Turkestan and Tomsk. The delegates have appealed to M. Witte (R.)

div.head: CAPE TO CAIRO.
PROGRESS OF THE RAILWAY.
RECORD CONSTRUCTION.
div.p: Reuter's representative has had an interview with Sir Charles Metcalfe, who has just return- ed to England on the conclusion of an inter esting journey from the Zambesi to the Congo Free State border. Discussing the progress of the Cape to Cairo railway, Sir Charles Metcalfe said: "A fortnight ago the rails reached the Kafue River, 260 miles beyond the Victoria Falls, and at this point a bridge 1,600ft long is being constructed to cross the stream. Beyond the Kafue the earthworks are nearly finished for a further distance of seventy miles, so that we hope that the line will reach the Broken Hill zinc and lead mines by June. There will thus be con tinuous communication from Cape Town to a point 374 miles north of the Zumbesi. The line is progressing at the rate of one mile a day. On one occasion, however, we managed to lay 5 3/4 miles in ten hours. A French engineer who had been constructing railways in French West Africa and was visiting Rhodesia would not at first believe that construction could go on at a greater rate than half a mile a day, and in order to show him what we could do and our method of working, we laid a quarter of a mile in twenty minutes. "My recent journey to the Congo border had partly for its object a preliminary survey of the regions beyond Broken Hill. While nothing has yet been definitely decided as to the farther extension, it is probable that the next section of the line will go from Broken Hill due north to Bwone Macubwa, a point on the Congo border, and the centre of a rich copper area in north west Rhodesia, where there are a fes whites developing the copper mines. The region is fine, open, and hilly. "In times past there has been taken out of the hill side copper ore in two parallel cuts, one about 12ft wide, and tin other 5ft wide, and both run close together for a distance of 3,000ft. Under the hill are caves of green malachite, which is very rich in copper. The country all round was well watered, and having an altitude of 4,500ft, was qute cool at night. The whole of the region is peaceful and secure, presenting a great contrast to the con dition of affairs a few years ago. The natives are now free from the raids from which they suffered, and enjoy security of property. They recognise the benefits of a chartered company's control."

div.head: AT THE TEWFIK PALACE
CONCERT FOR UGANDA MISSION.
div.p: Visitors at Helouan spent a delightful evening on Wednesday last, when an entertain ment was given at the Tewfik Palace Hotel in aid of the Uganda Mission. With the aid of the management a most picturesque stage had been created at one end of the spacious hall and the other part was crowded with over one hundred and fifty visitors. The chief attraction consisted of a series of tableaux of nursery rhymes with modernized versions in which the following took part : Miss Beutley, Miss K. Bentley, Miss Hint, Miss Phillips, Miss Woodle, Mr. A. Bentley, Mr. W. Bentley, Lt. G. Cory, Mr. Mills, and "Jepp," who, as Mother Hubbard's dog, was inimitable. Between the tableaux there were songs and recitations, among which a whistling solo with auto-harp accompaniment by Miss Tottenham and a most apropos recitation about the "Cairo and Elwan Express," by Mr. Hans Sawyer, deserve special mention. Miss Breeze and Mrs. Phillips also sang, and the Rev. C. H Banning gave a reading. At the close a hearty vote of thanks was passed to Mrs. Freeman for organiz- ing the entertainment, to Mrs. Mills for arranging the tableaux and Mr. Sawyer for superintending the erection of the stage. A special word of praise is due to the manage ment of the hotel on account of the excellent arrangements made for the occasion. The creditable sum of over L.E 16 has been for warded to the Mission. Over thirty people have booked accommoda- tion at the Tewfik Palace Hotel for Beyram, and this hotel promises to be the rendez-vous of a large and select party during the feast Besides picnics and other outdoor amuse- ments, the stabling, which is unique, offers an opportunity for those who go in for riding for which the surrounding desert is to justly celebrated. Visitors at the hotel can witness every morning the training of over forty race horses on the course immediately adjoining the hotel. The second race meeting will take place on Friday next at 2 p.m. and those desirous of reserving tables for luncheon are advised to give notice beforehand to the management as the dining room is generally more than fall on these occasions. During luncheon a string band, will perform a selection of classical music. Combined Tewfik race tickets, including railway fare, luncheon, tea, and entrance to members' enclosure stand and paddock, are obtainable at Stephenson and Co., chemist, Opera sip are, Shepheard's Hotel (hall porter), and at the booking office at Babel Look railway station, at P.T. 55 for gentlemen and P.T. 40 for ladies.

div.head: FOOTBALL.
VICTORIA COLLEGE v. E.T.C.
div.p: This match was played on the school ground on Saturday week and resulted in a win for the College by 3 goals to 1. The Eastern Telegraph Co. had not their full strength.
FOOTBALL CUP TIE

"Onlooker" (Cairo) writes:- Will you allow me through the columns of your most valuable paper to make a few remarks on the game on Saturday between the two famous Fusilier Regiments? I should like to know who was responsible for the arrangement of such an important game. Did they think there were no linesmen required and that as long as there was a referee there it was sufficient? And why did the referee start the game before he was certain that he had these important men which in all cases should be neutral and not two men of the one corps, namely the Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, also there men should be competent men and not men to argue with players. The game from start to finish was well contested, the first half opened well in favour of the Dubs and with the sun in their faces kept their opponents very busy in defending their goal, but the better training of the Cairo men soon gave them the advantage and they soon gave Rice plenty to do. The goal scored by the outside right was a splendid piece of work and right before half time a fumble between goalkeeper and back gave Lusy a chance to equalize, which he did in fine style. The second half opened well for the Cairo men, who rushed away, and Rice was called on to throw away close to goal. The outside left got the ball and passed to the inside right, who scored; this man was offside but the referee failed to see it and allowed the goal. Another regrettable thing happened shortly afterwards; a linesman raised his flag the referee did not see it and the Skills scored again. the was allowed amid the joy of their supporters until the Dubs appealed, and the mistake was rectified. Handling amongst the Dubs was very prevalent but the referee could not see it and again the ball was more than once behind the goal line and was still allowed to be played. On the whole the refereeing left very much to be desired. The defense of the Dubs was far in advance of their opponents, but the Cairo team had the beet set of forwards. The goal keeping by Rice could not be better and he well merited the applause he received from all present. The game was more like a friendly than a Cup tie, both sets of players acted like gentlemen, on no occasion was the referee called on to sound his whistle for anything in the ships of fouls except offside and hands. A draw would have been right. I hope better arrangements will be made when the final takes place and that the necessary linesmen will be obtained before the game starts.

div.head: GYMKHANA At ASSOUAN
div.p: Yesterday was the first Gymkhana we have held here this season. The beautifully laid out lawns and flower gardens of the Savoy not being available for the noble Egyptian donkey to be galloped on, the various events "came off" in the immense eastern gravelled courtyard of the Cataract Hotel. As the French say, it is "vieux cliche," but the day was spotless, and though the sun was very warm (about 112 F.) yet a cool and gentle breeze tempered the air. All the hotels sent nearly all their guests, and to the ordinary person suddenly transplanted here from Europe on an Aladdin's carpet or a lightning-speed Cook's ticket, the scene would have been unbelievable, given the date. The ladies' dresses were many of them very beautiful and the flushed and excited appearance of the many young people lent a degree of merriment and spirit to the operations uncommon in these local fetes. The spectators occupied seats on the great terrace of the hotel, while long rows of elegantly-dressed people were to the right and left Royalty, beauty, and good humour made everything perfect, while the proceedings, under the guidance of one of our frequent and well-known visitors (Mr. Pembroke) passed off without a hitch. The following were the winters in the various events:- Ladies' Donkey Race-—1st, Miss Mosler ; 2nd, Miss Dotte. Cigarette and Soda Race.—1st, Mr. E.T. Whitehouse. div.head: AN ARABIC VOCABULARY FOR THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN SUDAN.
div.p: Captain H. F. S. Amery has compiled an English-Arabic vocabulary primarily for the use of British officers and officials serving in the Anglo Egyptian Sudan. But it is hoped that it may also prove of some use to visitors to the Sudan, or to those interested in the various dialects of the Arabic language. The work consists of two distinct elements :—(1) The technical terms in use in the Egyptian Army and in the various departments of the Sudan Government; (2) some 3 500 words of the most common daily usage translated into the Arabic equivalents employed for those in conversation among the Arabs of the Anglo Egyptian Sudan. The British official, on arrival in the Sudan, has immediately to direct his attention to the acquisition of an extremely difficult language. His difficulties have hitherto been enormously increased by the lack of proficient teachers and the practical absence of any printed assistance. Each new comer has to pick up a large number of most accessary words as best he can, with the result that he is often content with learning just sufficient to enable him to make his meaning intelligible, or to pass the various Government examinations, and even this minimum he acquires more slowly than necessary. At present no English Arabic vocabulary or dictionary (of reasonable dimensions) exists, which contains even a fraction of the technical terms in daily use in the Army or in the various branches of the Civil Government, nor are any of the many vocabularies of colloquial Arabic of use in the Sudan, except perhaps in Khartoum and a few other towns where the population has come much into contact with Egyptians and Syrians. The object, therefore, of this vocabulary is to enable an official on entering the Sudan to find the particular technical terms which are in use in the Egyptian Army, or the department to which be is attached, and also the Arabic for such words as he is likely to require to carry on a simple conversation. It it stated in the preface that "there is some danger that the Sudan Arabs, in ignorance of the eloquence and purity of their language, may adopt some of the colloquialism of Egypt, as they come into contact with the Egyptian and Syrian officials. But the spread of education, the study of the Koran and of the classical Arabic should do much to counteract this influence." *English Arabic Vocabulary for the use of officers and officials. Compiled in the Intelligence Office, Sudan Government. May be obtained from the Director of Intelligence, Cairo, or Assistant Director of Intelligence, Khartoum, P.T. 60.

div.head: RETRIBUTION.
div.p: To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette. Sir, —Though I am well aware that a controversy regarding home politics would be out of place in your columns, yet bearing in mind the engrossing interest which Englishmen of all shades of opinion most necessarily take at the present juncture in the nations affairs, I would crave leave for a little of your valuable space to reply to your leader under the above heading. The writer assumes with that air of assurance habitual to his class and calling that the British electorate have changed their public servants because of the disunion which existed within their ranks, and likewise from a good humoured sort of feeling that it was time to give the other side a turn. My knowledge of our people leads me to diverge from this view. From what I saw and heard when last in England a few months ago, everyone, even the Unionists themselves outside official circles, were tired of Mr. Balfour's Government, which, if it had possessed a shadow of a shade of decency and self-respect, would have resigned two years previously. That regime, from the time that the next prominent and trusted politicians dissociated themselves from their colleagues and the Cabinet was re-constituted of untried and, therefore unqualified, functionaries, forfeited in toto the confidence of the people. In their eyes, thenceforth, Mr. Balfour's Administration stood for privilege and patronage, the upholder of snobbery and jobbery, which drew within its folds those whose only claims to preferment were pride of birth and wealthy connections. The British people may be conservative in many things but they are democrats in their abhorrence of "flunkey-ism" in all its phases. Still the Government held on, aye, held on by mean and contemptible devices, by resorting to shams, to shifts, and subterfuges which outraged every sense of public rectitude and political propriety. Mr. Balfout and his satellites had long ceased to represent the sentiments or conform to the wishes of the nation. They were no longer the faithful and obedient servants of the public but had become its domineering, arrogant, and tyrannical masters. With their exaggerated and exasperating Imperialism they constituted themselves the prototype not of bluff John Bull but of blustering John Bully. And so at the very first opportunity given to the people to express an Opinion upon their shameful dereliction of public duty and degradation of political life Mr. Balfour's Administration has been dismissed by a crushing defeat at the polls, in spite of all the red herrings that were employed to obscure the real issue. That the people should have thus spoken, and with no uncertain voice, affords once again convincing and unmistakable proof of their unconquerable common-sense, their manly independence, and their unfaltering love of equality and justice.
Vex Populi. Cairo, January 27.

div.head: MERCHANT SEAMEN'S HOME.
div.p: On Thursday evening, the 25 h inst. the annual tea and entertainment given by the ladies of Ramleh took place at the Home under the organization of Mr R J Moss. Many willing helpers were busily engaged during the afternoon in preparing the table for the sailors, who arrived at 6 30, numbering fully 200, and sat down to enjoy the ample repast provided. Daring the supper, each man was presented with a packet of tobacco and New Year's card (the gift of Mrs Moss) and a "buttonhole." After all had partaken heartily, the tables were cleared and the musical portion commenced, the Rev. Canon Ward kindly toting as chairman. All the Kings, recitations and instrumental items were received with appreciative applause. Many "encores" were called for and readily given. The concluding number was the comical sketch entitled "Black Justice," given by the nigger troupe of the Moss S.S. Seti, the humorously illegal decisions of Justice Grabball and the eccentric behaviour of both policeman and prisoners causing much merriment. On the proposal of the chairman, three hearty cheers were given for the King and Royal Family, which were followed by three more for the ladies of Ramleh and a very pleasant evening terminated at 10 o'clock with another three cheers for the chairman and the singing of the National Anthem. It was a pleasing incident to notice amongst the audience nine boys of the Blind Industrial School who came under the charge of Mr. Wood, the manager of the school. They fully enjoyed the entertainment and have testified their appreciation by sending a touching letter of thanks, in which Mr. Wood says:- "To-night, after fes, they elected their chairman and he told all the other boys to whom they were indebted for the good fare and then called for three cheers for the ladies of Ramleh to which they all responded in a very hearty manner. Special thanks are due to the captains of the S.S. Seti, Menes, Moeris and Fabian, for lending flags for decoration. The following was the programme:-song, "The Motor Car," Mr. H. E. C. Moss ; songs, "Quick Work" and "I burst out laughing," Mr. D. Allen ; song, "Good-bye." Miss Alderson ; vocal duet, "When the Wind blows in from the Sea," Mrs. W. R. Williams and Miss Williams ; recitations, Mr. H. O. Smithers ; song, "For All Eternity," Mrs. Ed. G. C. Moss ; violin solo, Nautical Airs, Miss Hewat ; songs, "Because" and "To Anthes," Mr. J. K. Clarkson ; song, "Where're you go" Miss P. O. E. Moss ; violin solo. Mr. H. V. Hall, song, "I live in Trafalgar Square," Mr. D. Allen ; recitations, Mr. H. O. Smithers. The following was the "caste" of "Black Justice" :-Justice Grabball,Mr. J. Walsh ; Peter Pipeclay, K.C., Mr. g. Seiffurt ; P.C. Jackson, Mr. F. Duncanson ; Prisoners, Messrs. May, Cowan, Aspinall, and Warbreck. The list of contributers to the feast is as follows: Mrs. Adamson, Mrs Alderson, Mrs A Alderson, Miss Alderson, Mrs Douglas, Allan, Mrs Kenneth Aitken, Mrs. and Miss Atkin, Mrs. John Atkin, Mrs, Archer, Mrs. R. Recolte nxxmelle: Eu commerve a achere dans l'aores-midi et cela a contribue a raffermir les cours. En cloture nous acons au une legere reaction, mais quand meme nous resions en benefice de 7/82 sur la coture de 1 heure.

div.head: CONTRATS, (11h.55 a.m.)
div.p: Cours de la Bourse de Minet-el-Bassal
REMARQUES
Cotons: Nouvelle récolte.—Le novembre a ouvert à 16 1/2 sous l'impression de la clôture d'Amérique et ne tarde même pas à fléchir à 14 7/8, mais il se raffermit de nouveau. Affaires claisemées.
Récolte actuelle. —Juillet a débuté à 14 5/16 et reste soutenu. Marché peu animé.
Grains de coton: Nouvelle récolte.— Sans affaires importante; quand même les cours sont bien tenus.
Récolte actuelle.—Juillet a obtenu P.T. 58 ¾ à l'ouverture.
Fèves-Saidi: Nouvelle récolte.—Marché nul.
